President Goodnow has as yet
taken no definite action upon
the petition submitted to him by
the Omicron Delta Kappa that a
committee composed of undergraduates, graduates, faculty and
alumni be appointed by hint to
consider the general athletic situation at Hopkins and to shape a
policy for the future.
While expressing great pleasure
at the concerted consideration of
Hopkins problems which the petition showed to be in evidence,
the president deemed the action
requested to be too important—
too widespread in its results—to
be taken too hastily. For that
reason, he has called into consultation several of the alumni most
prominently connected with Hopkins' affairs, and wishes to consult with several more before his
final decision is announced.
The committee which presented
the petition to the president on
behalf of the Omicron Delta Kappa consisted of John C. Knipp,
president of the circle; Alexander
M. Wolfe, secretary; and Reuben
Oppenheimer.
The petition first called attention to the evident need for some
action which would represent the
opinion of the entire University—
a need which was made clear both
by the condition of athletics at
Hopkins and by the general sentiment. It then requested that
the president appoint a committee composed of undergraduates,
graduates, faculty and alumni,
which should carefully consider
every phase of athletics at Hopkins, and which should frame a
policy to be followed consistently
in future years.
While no definite statement can
be made at the present time, it is
extremely probable that the next
issue Of THE NEWS - LETTER will
contain President Goodnow's announcement as to his decision
upon the petition. The president
recently stated to a member of
the Omicron Delta Kappa committee that he regretted that any
delay was necessary, that he was
endeavoring to expedite matters
as much as possible and that he
expected to come to a decision in
the very near future.

By A. E. LINDLEY

General Secretary of the Y. M. C. A.

The recent campaign to raise
funds for the men in the prison
camps of Europe was highly successful. Although the entire $1,000, which we set as our goal, was
not raised, we feel that it was a
splendid showing for the Hopkins
men. It has demonstrated that
the Hopkins men are of the right
calibre when a worthy cause is
presented to them. The Hopkins
men responded to this call equally
as well as the men in any of the
colleges and universities in this
country who have been waging
campaigns for the same purpose.
Some of the institutions have
given larger amounts, but the
average of Hopkins has been as
great. During this campaign,
more money was given by students than at any previous time
in the history of the University.
While this movement was started by the Y. M. C. A. and was
largely carried on by members of
this organization, all felt that it
was a movement in which all
students and members of the
faculty could co operate. Men
were brought face to face with the
conditions of our fellow-students
in Europe and felt a desire to
make life a little bit easier for
these men. Many students sacrificed in order that they might help
in forwarding this unselfish cause
—a number of men giving up personal pleasures, thus enabling
them to give to this fund.
The actual work was done by
four teams representing the student body. Fifty men in all were
active in the campaign. All who
gave to this fund gave freely.
They gave in 'order that they
might share a little with our fellow-students on the other side.
We can never know the full value
of this giving. It has eased many
a pain and has given many a fellow a new hope for the future.
On behalf of the Y. M. C. A.
and those men who were back of
this movement, we wish to thank
all those who contributed, both
members of the faculty and students, either by giving of money
or time. All has been greatly
appreciated and we feel has been
given in the right direction.

LIBRARY RECEIVES RICH GIFT
Professor Berkley Presents University
with Many Valuable Old Medical
Books—One "A Compleat Capital Method of Physick."

Dr. Henry J. Berkley, clinical
professor of psychiatry in the
Johns Hopkins University, has
just presented the University library with a number of rare and
valuable medical books, dating
from the sixteenth, seventeenth
and eighteenth centuries.
Dr. Berkley has picked up these
books in the last twenty-five or
thirty years in various trips
abroad. Nearly all of the books
are in their original bindings, and
many of them contain interesting
book plates,excellent frontispieces
and numerous wood cuts and engravings. An added interest in
many of them consist in the autographs of the several men who have
in turn owned them. Most of the
books are in Latin, but several
are in German and English.
There are several editions of Hippocrates, with the Greek and
Latin texts on opposite pages';
and there are also several copies

of Celsus—a book which has been
used in medical schools in Baltimore within rather recent times.
Among the collection is a copy
of a quaint book of Culpepper's,
called "The English Physician,"
containing a "compleat capital
Method of Physick, whereby a
Man may preserve his Body in
Health, or Cure himself, being
Sick, for Three Pence Charge."
One passage, in regard to plums,
remarks that "all plums are under Venus and are like women,
some better, some worse." Another is as follows: "There is a
Syrup made of lore-hound to be
had at the Apothecaries, very
good for old Coughs, to rid the
tough Flegm as also to avoid
cold Rheums from the Lungs of
old Folks, and for those that are
Asthmatick or short winded."
The paper on which most of
these books are printed is marvelous when compared with the
flimsy paper of today, and the
printing is still just as clear as it
was three hundred years ago. Dr.
Berkley has often pointed out the
quality of the paper in old books
—being one of the best judges in
the United States of the quality
of paper.

CLASS DEBATE TRYOUTS MONDAY
Senior and Junior Teams to Be Chosen.
Subject for Tryouts, Compulsory
Arbitration of Labor Disputes
in Public Utilities.

Tryouts for the senior and
junior debating teams will take
place on Monday, January 15, at
12.50 P. M., in the Civil Engineering Assembly Hall.
The subject for the tryouts is
the one submitted by the Debating Council for the Virginia-North
Carolina-Hopkins triangle.
It
reads: "Resolved that, constitutionality waived, legislation providing for the compulsory arbitration of labor disputes in public utilities and prohibiting all
strikes and lockouts in such utilities should be enacted."
The speeches of the contestants
will be limited to four minutes,
with a short period for rebuttal.
Each team is composed of three
speakers, alternate' and adviser.
The interclass debate will take
place on March 3.
In all probability, the subject
for the interclass tryouts, or some
variant of it, will be the subject
of the 'varsity triangular debate.
Both North Carolina and Virginia
have submitted their subjects, but
the final choice has not yet been
made. The subject submitted by
Virginia, however, is practically
the same as that of Hopkins,
varying only in the matter of
wording. North Carolina proposes as its subject, government
ownership and operation of railroads.
The discussion of compulsory
arbitration of labor disputes in
public utilities as a matter of
governmental policy has become a
vital one, and -seems this year to
predominate in college debating
Only recircles everywhere.
cently, it formed the subject for
the debate between Columbia and
New York universities, the two
largest in the country.
By fixing the date of the interclass ccintest for March 3, the
Council endeavored to afford ample time for preparation, while
not placing it too near the 'varsity debates, which will take place
towards the end of April.
The subject for the tryouts will
not necessarily be the subject of
the interclass debate, as that subject will be the one selected for
the triangle. The Council hopes,
however, that the final choice will
have been wade some time next
week.
Dr. John C. French will judge
the tryouts. All members of the
senior and junior classes are eligible for competition.

Class of 1912 Has Theatre Party and
I anquet— Class Play Reacted—History of Class Since Graduation
an Unusual One.

Many Hopkins Men Eligible to Take
Competitive Examination for Assistant Examiner in U. S. Patent
Office—Salary, $1,500.

On Wednesday, December 27,
the Class of 1912 held its fifth
annual reunion. In the afternoon,
the class had a theatre party at
Ford's, seeing "Turn to the
Right" this was followed by a reenacting of ,the 1912 class play
and by a dinner at the Emerson
in the evening.
The Class of 1912, at the time
of its graduation, had forty-seven
members, of whom an approximate half were present at the reunion. A feature of the occasion was the distribution of a
very artistic booklet, which contained the class play and a history of what every member of the
class has done since he has left
Hopkins.
The list of professions in which
the members of the class are now
engaged is a comprehensive one,
ranging from teaching and research to law, business and sociological work.
No better tribute could be paid
to the undergraduate department
of Johns Hopkins University than
the success which has come to
the members of one of its classes,
even in the short period of five
years. Men who, five years ago,
smoked their pipes in undergraduate nonchalance in the basement
of McCoy Hall, are now managers
of large businesses, partners in
• law firms, successful authors,
quoted authorities in various
fields of study.
The 1912 class play, which was
reacted in full, is entitled "Everystudent," and was written by H.
Graham DuBois, now. graduate
student in English at Hopkins
and master at St. Paul's School.

1916 WAS RECORD COLLEGE YEAR
Sets New Mark in History of American
Education—Many Universities Changing Entrance Requirements-11
Have Over 5,000 Students.

A rather comprehensive summary of the development of American colleges and universities in
1916 was given recently by the
Boston Evening Transcript. According to this estimate, "regis-tration figures from more than
half a hundred American institutions of higher learning ten the
same story of capacity enrollments."
"To many institutions," the report continues, "growing enrollments present a, serious problem.
With present accommodations
taxed to the limit, there Pare apparently only two courses open.
Registration may be kept where
it is by a rigorous application of
the 'first come, first served' principle, or ways and means for increasing accommodations must be
devised. Oberlin and Vassar, for
instance, are committed to the
policy of limiting the number of
students they will receive. The
State universities, on the other
hand,.are inclined to let all enter
who will an'd trust to the legislators to provide the funds for
new buildings and more teachers:
Years ago our colleges found it
a difficult task to grow; now,it is
just as hard for them tb.: keep
small.
."From Princeton come two am
nouncements of more than local
significance. The first is to the
effect that the proportion of high
school boys entering the university is steadily growing. Private
School graduates are still in the
'majority, but their lead is a slender one. The inference is plain.
The action taken by Harvard,
Yale and Princeton to broaden
their entrance requirements has
done just what the universities
hoped it would do. It has made
it possible for the average boy to
enter these three great endowed
institutions. Specialized training
for admission examinations — a
service which the small city or
town high school cannot perform
—is no longer essential. Intellectual ability, expressed in no
matter what terms, is all that is
needed. For the concessions involved in this new policy, the
country boy in particular is grateful. To him it means the opening
of new opportunities. But the universities are glad that they acted
as they did.
"The other Princeton statement
declares that the scholarship of
this year's freshman class is considerably higher than that of its
predecessor. The boys now entering the universitly are better prepa cd a wi consequently better fitted to carry on the work of the
college classroom. This should
be an answer to those who feared
that admission requirements had

been lowered rather than broadened.
"The Harvard - Yale- Princeton
policy of basing admission on
quality rather than quantity of
scholarship has also been adopted
by four women's colleges — Mt.
Holyoke, Smith, Vassar and Wellesley. In 1919 the present
method of admission by certif.cate will be abandoned and in its
place will be the so-called comprehensive examination p1 a n,
which depends on two kinds of
evidence—the candidate's record
in the preparatory school and examinations in four major subjects. Discussing the change, the
official announcement from the
four colleges says:
"'It is believed that this new
type of admission combines the
best elements of the present certificate system and of the examination system in that it requires
the school record and estimate of
character, and also demands examinations designed to test the
candidate's intellectual power,
not alone her memory 'of prescribed facts. Furthermore, the
method offers the applicant the
fullest opportunity to show her
ability in which she believes herself best qualified.
"'This plan substitutes a: uniform method of administration in
place of the various certificate
forms now .used by the four colleges and gives the school entire
freedom in the sequence of its
work, making no requirement of
certain subjects in the last years.'
"Returning to registration figures, it appears that in the number of actual students pursuing
definite courses, New York University now leads the country.
This was an honor that was supposedly Columbia's. But Columbia's numerical strength lies
largely in its summer school and
extension courses. The statistics
also show that a good many universities boast enrollments exceeding five thousand and indicate to what an extent higher education has become popularized.
It is difficult to estimate, of
course, how many thousands of
Americans of all ages are within
the circle of influence of the university, but extension courses are
flourishing everywhere—the United States mail carries learning
to the remotest points and summer sessions were never so popular. Columbia alone, through
the medium of its extra-curricular activities, annually reaches
more than twenty thousand people. The big universities of the
country, all of them having a registration exceeding five thousand,
in alphabetical order, are: Columbia, Cornell, New York University, Northwestern, Ohio State
and the Universities of California, Illinois, Michigan, Minnesota, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. Several institutions, including Harvard, are just under the
five thousand mark."

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir — The work in military
training started off very well, as
everyone knows, but at present
"pep" seems to be lacking in the
drills. The men trifle, talk, and
are generally inattentive. It is
true that it may happen that a
command is not given loud enough
for the entire organization to
hear, but this sort of thing will
not occur very often if the men
are attentive and are trying.
The positions at attention while
at a halt and while marching are
none too good. These things can
be remedied very easily by a little
thought upon the part of each individual. The file closers are
expected to correct these faults,
but they have enough to do without having to correct the position
of each individual.
The lieutenants, it is true, have
had but little more training than
the other men of the battalion,
but it is only fair to their company—the men under them—that
they study up on their'drill regulations and know the work well
enough, not , only • to give commands — that's easy — but to explain movements and to conduct
the company as well as the captain. It is not very much of an
inducement to the company to
work for a man who hesitates and
mumbles his commands and shows
that he knows no more about running a company than the men
themselves.
The commissioned and noncommissioned officers (sergeants
and corporals) are not selected
because of their beauty, but because they know something about
their jobs. When a man in the
ranks is addressed by a "noncom," it is his place to do as he
is told, to do it quickly and to
keep his mouth shut. And since
these men are put above the
others to make corrections, it is
up to them to make some corrections—not unnecessary remarks,
but helpful corrections.
Let every man in the corps take
a larger interest in the work, pay
strict attention at drill and lectures, and the interst in the
work will get back to the point
it was when first started, the advance of the course will be much
more rapid, and all will get a lot
more benefit from the training.

Johns Hopkins University, has
just presented the University library with a number of rare and
valuable medical books, dating
from the sixteenth, seventeenth
and eighteenth centuries.
Dr. Berkley has picked up these
books in the last twenty-five or
thirty years in various trips
abroad. Nearly all of the books
are in their original bindings, and
many of them contain interesting
book plates,excellent frontispieces
and numerous wood cuts and engravings. An added interest in
many of them consist in the autographs of the several men who have
in turn owned them. Most of the
books are in Latin, but several
are in German and English.
There are several editions of Hippocrates, with the Greek and
Latin texts on opposite pages';
and there are also several copies

of Celsus—a book which has been
used in medical schools in Baltimore within rather recent times.
Among the collection is a copy
of a quaint book of Culpepper's,
called "The English Physician,"
containing a "compleat capital
Method of Physick, whereby a
Man may preserve his Body in
Health, or Cure himself, being
Sick, for Three Pence Charge."
One passage, in regard to plums,
remarks that "all plums are under Venus and are like women,
some better, some worse." Another is as follows: "There is a
Syrup made of lore-hound to be
had at the Apothecaries, very
good for old Coughs, to rid the
tough Flegm as also to avoid
cold Rheums from the Lungs of
old Folks, and for those that are
Asthmatick or short winded."
The paper on which most of
these books are printed is marvelous when compared with the
flimsy paper of today, and the
printing is still just as clear as it
was three hundred years ago. Dr.
Berkley has often pointed out the
quality of the paper in old books
—being one of the best judges in
the United States of the quality
of paper.

1916 WAS RECORD COLLEGE YEAR
Sets New Mark in History of American
Education—Many Universities Changing Entrance Requirements-11
Have Over 5,000 Students.

A rather comprehensive summary of the development of American colleges and universities in
1916 was given recently by the
Boston Evening Transcript. According to this estimate, "regis-tration figures from more than
half a hundred American institutions of higher learning ten the
same story of capacity enrollments."
"To many institutions," the report continues, "growing enrollments present a, serious problem.
With present accommodations
taxed to the limit, there Pare apparently only two courses open.
Registration may be kept where
it is by a rigorous application of
the 'first come, first served' principle, or ways and means for increasing accommodations must be
devised. Oberlin and Vassar, for
instance, are committed to the
policy of limiting the number of
students they will receive. The
State universities, on the other
hand,.are inclined to let all enter
who will an'd trust to the legislators to provide the funds for
new buildings and more teachers:
Years ago our colleges found it
a difficult task to grow; now,it is
just as hard for them tb.: keep
small.
."From Princeton come two am
nouncements of more than local
significance. The first is to the
effect that the proportion of high
school boys entering the university is steadily growing. Private
School graduates are still in the
'majority, but their lead is a slender one. The inference is plain.
The action taken by Harvard,
Yale and Princeton to broaden
their entrance requirements has
done just what the universities
hoped it would do. It has made
it possible for the average boy to
enter these three great endowed
institutions. Specialized training
for admission examinations — a
service which the small city or
town high school cannot perform
—is no longer essential. Intellectual ability, expressed in no
matter what terms, is all that is
needed. For the concessions involved in this new policy, the
country boy in particular is grateful. To him it means the opening
of new opportunities. But the universities are glad that they acted
as they did.
"The other Princeton statement
declares that the scholarship of
this year's freshman class is considerably higher than that of its
predecessor. The boys now entering the universitly are better prepa cd a wi consequently better fitted to carry on the work of the
college classroom. This should
be an answer to those who feared
that admission requirements had

been lowered rather than broadened.
"The Harvard - Yale- Princeton
policy of basing admission on
quality rather than quantity of
scholarship has also been adopted
by four women's colleges — Mt.
Holyoke, Smith, Vassar and Wellesley. In 1919 the present
method of admission by certif.cate will be abandoned and in its
place will be the so-called comprehensive examination p1 a n,
which depends on two kinds of
evidence—the candidate's record
in the preparatory school and examinations in four major subjects. Discussing the change, the
official announcement from the
four colleges says:
"'It is believed that this new
type of admission combines the
best elements of the present certificate system and of the examination system in that it requires
the school record and estimate of
character, and also demands examinations designed to test the
candidate's intellectual power,
not alone her memory 'of prescribed facts. Furthermore, the
method offers the applicant the
fullest opportunity to show her
ability in which she believes herself best qualified.
"'This plan substitutes a: uniform method of administration in
place of the various certificate
forms now .used by the four colleges and gives the school entire
freedom in the sequence of its
work, making no requirement of
certain subjects in the last years.'
"Returning to registration figures, it appears that in the number of actual students pursuing
definite courses, New York University now leads the country.
This was an honor that was supposedly Columbia's. But Columbia's numerical strength lies
largely in its summer school and
extension courses. The statistics
also show that a good many universities boast enrollments exceeding five thousand and indicate to what an extent higher education has become popularized.
It is difficult to estimate, of
course, how many thousands of
Americans of all ages are within
the circle of influence of the university, but extension courses are
flourishing everywhere—the United States mail carries learning
to the remotest points and summer sessions were never so popular. Columbia alone, through
the medium of its extra-curricular activities, annually reaches
more than twenty thousand people. The big universities of the
country, all of them having a registration exceeding five thousand,
in alphabetical order, are: Columbia, Cornell, New York University, Northwestern, Ohio State
and the Universities of California, Illinois, Michigan, Minnesota, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. Several institutions, including Harvard, are just under the
five thousand mark."

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir — The work in military
training started off very well, as
everyone knows, but at present
"pep" seems to be lacking in the
drills. The men trifle, talk, and
are generally inattentive. It is
true that it may happen that a
command is not given loud enough
for the entire organization to
hear, but this sort of thing will
not occur very often if the men
are attentive and are trying.
The positions at attention while
at a halt and while marching are
none too good. These things can
be remedied very easily by a little
thought upon the part of each individual. The file closers are
expected to correct these faults,
but they have enough to do without having to correct the position
of each individual.
The lieutenants, it is true, have
had but little more training than
the other men of the battalion,
but it is only fair to their company—the men under them—that
they study up on their'drill regulations and know the work well
enough, not , only • to give commands — that's easy — but to explain movements and to conduct
the company as well as the captain. It is not very much of an
inducement to the company to
work for a man who hesitates and
mumbles his commands and shows
that he knows no more about running a company than the men
themselves.
The commissioned and noncommissioned officers (sergeants
and corporals) are not selected
because of their beauty, but because they know something about
their jobs. When a man in the
ranks is addressed by a "noncom," it is his place to do as he
is told, to do it quickly and to
keep his mouth shut. And since
these men are put above the
others to make corrections, it is
up to them to make some corrections—not unnecessary remarks,
but helpful corrections.
Let every man in the corps take
a larger interest in the work, pay
strict attention at drill and lectures, and the interst in the
work will get back to the point
it was when first started, the advance of the course will be much
more rapid, and all will get a lot
more benefit from the training.
